Description: This virtual tour tells the history of the Yolo Basin Foundation and the geography of the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area.
Description 2: Scroll through the multimedia narrative and explore the accomanying map layers, or use the buttons above to jump to a particular chapter. You can also zoom in and out on the map using the +/- controls, and click to zoom/pan.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: The Central Valley, California's agricultural heartland, is an 18,000-square-mile sedimentary valley, fed by vast watershed of the Sacramento and San Joaquin Rivers.
Description 2: The valley's drainage area extends to the crests of the Sierra Nevada and the coast range, a catchment for rain and snowmelt that encompasses 60,000 square miles. Water from the Sacramento and San Joaquin Rivers and their tributaries converge at the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta—a highly modified landscape of tidal sloughs and canals surrounding levee-protected agricultural lowlands—before flowing out to sea via the San Francisco Bay.
Map Credit: Geospatial data sources: USGS NHD+, California Natural Resources Agency.

Description: Located in the northern Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta, the Yolo Basin is a vast, low-lying historic wetland area, filled by distributary streams from the west and Sacramento River overflow to the east.
Map Credit: Early 1900s USGS topographic maps (1:32000 and 1:64000 scale). 32k mosaic basemap layer published by California Department of Fish & Wildlife.

Description: One of the Basin's major western tributaries is Putah Creek, whose water historically spread out and infiltrated into the soil at the Putah Creek Sinks.
Media Credit: Putah Creek Sinks, 1850, showing Cowell Ranch and Glides Ranch in background.
Map Credit: Early 1900s USGS topographic maps (1:32000 and 1:64000 scale). 32k mosaic basemap layer published by California Department of Fish & Wildlife.

Description: The Central Valley was once a complex mosaic of grasslands and riparian forests, transitioning to freshwater wetlands and tidal channels at the Delta.
Description 2: The riparian forests lining rivers like the Sacramento and tributary streams like Putah and Cache Creeks had lush canopies of valley oak, sycamore, and cottonwood. Along the edges of the valley were foothills of valley oak savanna (roblar).
Media Credit: 1852 lithographs of the Sacramento River by William H. Dougal. Source: David Rumsey Map Collection.
Map Credit: Central Valley data from Central Valley Historic Mapping Project via DataBasin. Fine-scale mapping via San Francisco Estuary Institute (SFEI) Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta Historical Ecology Study. Categories are combined and adjusted for presentation.

Description: The Yolo Basin was covered in freshwater emergent tule wetland (or tulare in early Californian Spanish), flanked by seasonal wet meadows.
Description 2: At the Putah Creek sinks, el Río de los Putos branched out in distributary channels as it passed through a vast willow thicket (sausal). The San Francisco Estuary Institute (SFEI) reconstructed these historical ecological boundaries based on 18th to 19th century expedition reports and survey maps.
Media Credit: Laying tules in preparation for burning. Source: Sacramento Archives & Museum Collection Center via Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area Land Management Plan.
Map Credit: Central Valley data from Central Valley Historic Mapping Project via DataBasin. Fine-scale mapping via San Francisco Estuary Institute (SFEI) Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta Historical Ecology Study. Categories are combined and adjusted for presentation.

Description: Euro-American settlement began with the Mexican land grant ranchos, then expanded as the Delta's fertile soil attracted farmers and ranchers during the Gold Rush period.
Description 2: The natural levees on the banks of the Sacramento River supported settlements and farms, including the growing city of Sacramento (formerly known as New Helvetia).
Media Credit: Land grant boundary map of Laguna de Santos Callé showing Putah Creek, the Putah Creek Sinks, and the tulares. Source: Online Archive of California
Map Credit: Map of the Valley of the Sacramento including the Gold Region (1848) retrieved from David Rumsey Map Collection.

Description: Beginning with the Swamp Land Act of 1850, earthen flood control levees and irrigation canals were constructed to support Delta farming by 'reclaiming' seasonal wetlands like the Yolo Basin.
Description 2: Settlements in the Sacramento Valley continued to grow, vulnerable to rising river levels from winter storms and spring snowmelt that culminated in the destructive flood of 1862.
Map Credit: State Engineer's Map of Northern California (1884) retrieved from David Rumsey Map Collection.

Description: In 1917, the US Congress authorized the Sacramento River Flood Control Project, a system of levees and weirs that direct flood waters away from developed areas and into the designated undeveloped Sutter and Yolo bypasses.
Description 2: The westside levees south of Interstate-80 were not completed until after World War II.
Media Credit: Animated overview of the Sacramento River Flood Control System produced by the US Army Corps of Engineers
Map Credit: Geospatial data sources: USGS NHD+, California Natural Resources Agency, SACOG.

Description: The 92-square-mile Yolo Bypass begins at Fremont Weir near Knights Landing, along the Sacramento River and extends south to the Delta. The Fremont Weir is located just below the junction of the Feather River and Sacramento Rivers.
Description 2:
The Fremont Weir is a 2 mile wide low concrete structure where Sacramento River flood water flows into the Yolo Bypass. When river stage exceeds 32 feet,Sacramento River flood waters flow over the Fremont moving south while also rising from the east side toe drain and expanding westward. Fully inundated, the Yolo Bypass becomes a vast "inland sea," conveying flood waters from eastside and westside sources across the Yolo Basin floodplain, re-entering the Sacramento River near Prospect and Liberty Islands.

The California Department of Water Resources can manually open and close the Sacramento Weir located on the eastside of the Bypass near I-80 bridge over the Sacramento River near West Sacramento. DWR staff remove boards on the Sacramento Weir to let in additional water from the Sacramento and American Rivers. This water flows west through the Sacramento Bypass and meets up with the Yolo Bypass.

The Bypass also receives periodic inflow from Cache Creek, Knights Landing Ridge Cut, Willow Slough and Willow Slough Bypass. Putah Creek provides a perennial inflow into the east side toe drain. During flood events these westside tributaries provide fast rising, uncontrolled flood waters into the Bypass. Uncontrolled westside flood flows can occur before, during or after the Fremont Weir spills.
Map Credit: Geospatial data sources: USGS NHD+, California Natural Resources Agency, SACOG.

Description: The different sources of water are visible in this aerial photograph from the March-April 2011 storm, owing to the varying sediment loads in the Sacramento River versus the tributary streams.
Map Credit: Aerial photo mosaic from the March-April 2011 flood event, showing visible sediment plumes corresponding to flows from the four major tributaries of the Yolo Bypass. Source: USGS High Resolution Orthoimagery (201104_sacramento_ca_0x3000m_utm_clr)

Description: Before the Yolo Causeway was built, there was no year-round route across the wetlands.
Description 2: A series of seasonal roads including the Tule Jack Road led through the tulares, as seen in this Gold Rush era map, but winter travelers had to venture across the flooded tule marshes by ferryboat, a dangerous crossing during high waters. To facilitate crossing the Yolo Bypass and expand commerce between Sacramento and the San Francisco Bay Area, the Yolo Causeway was built around the same time as the flood control project, in 1917.
Map Credit: Gold And Quicksilver District Of California (1848) retrieved from David Rumsey Historical Map Collection.

Description: One of the early settlers of the Yolo Basin was J.H. Glide, who purchased a large area in the 1870s that would eventually become much of the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area.
Description 2: The Glide family reclaimed the wetlands of the Putah Creek Sinks, turning thousands of acres into dry grazing land, and built a large and successful cattle and sheep business.
Map Credit: Official Map of Yolo County, California. Compiled from Official Records by C.C. Stitt, County Surveyor, 1939 retrieved from David Rumsey Historical Map Collection.

Description: The Yolo Bypass is an important stop along the Pacific Flyway, a north-south migratory pathway along which hundreds of millions of birds travel each year. Sacramento Valley wetlands provide critical overwintering habitat for waterfowl, shorebirds, songbirds, and raptors that then return to the various points west and north including the Canadian Arctic for the summer.
Description 2: The lines on this map are GPS tracks of migratory ducks and geese collected by the USGS Dixon Field Station.
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: Over time, more and more wetland habitat in the Yolo Basin, the Delta and the greater Sacramento Valley was drained and converted to agricultural and urban land….
Map Credit: 1937 aerial photography for the Sacramento/San Joaquin Delta. Source: basemap layer published by California Department of Fish & Wildlife.

Description: …until by the 1990s, almost no remnant wetland habitat remained in the Yolo Basin.
Map Credit: 1993 aerial photography (USGS Digital Ortho Quads)

Chapter: Founding YBF and the Wildlife Area
Description: The origin story of the Yolo Basin Foundation and the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area is a story of partnerships. Creating and protecting these thousands of acres of wetland habitat required cooperation between local, state and federal agencies and private landowners, hunters and birdwatchers, farmers, and conservation organizations.
The story begins as a community effort, born at kitchen tables in Davis.
Description 2:
The original maps for a proposed wildlife area were drawn by two members of Yolo Audubon, Steve Chainey and Ted Beedy. They invited others to discuss their concept. The next step was to build support for the proposal by giving slide shows at the City of Davis Vets Memorial.

Building off the success of the Putah Creek Council in advocating for adequate flows for fish habitat during an ongoing drought, members of the Council organized Yolo Basin Working Group to explore the concept of re-creating wetlands at the Putah Creek Sinks, the creek's downstream destination.

Description: Recognizing that most of the potential land for a wetland restoration was privately owned, the Working Group decided to work with—instead of in opposition to—local landowners.
Description 2: In February 1990, the Yolo Basin Working Group sponsored a meeting with area landowners and the California Department of Fish and Game, at the California Trucking Association Building in West Sacramento, to discuss the proposal for a Yolo Basin Wildlife Area. At that meeting, the Department of Fish and Game committed to working with the community on creation of a wildlife area at the Putah Creek Sinks, if it could be determined that an adequate water supply existed to manage wetlands.

Description: Later the same month, the Yolo Basin Foundation was officially founded to advocate for and coordinate the creation of a new State-owned and managed wildlife area which ultimately became the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area. The founding  board meeting was held at the kitchen table of Robin Kulakow and Bill Julian.

They sought the support of elected officials who would become critical advocates of the project's success, including Congressman Vic Fazio, Yolo County Supervisors Betsy Marchand and Helen Thomson, and City Councilwoman Lois Wolk.

Thanks to the wide-ranging collaboration and advocacy efforts, in December 1991, the State Wildlife Conservation Board completed the purchase of the 3100-acres of fallow ranch land—a portion of the Cowell Ranch then owned by Prudential Life Insurance—for $4.57 in funds from Proposition 70 and the State General Fund. The first milestone, land, was reached successfully.
In 1991, Richard Harris, then District Director for Congressman Vic Fazio met with Robin Kulakow and Bill Julian at their home in Davis.
Description 2: Fazio was interested in the wetlands project. They discussed various ways in which the Congressman could support it..  A few weeks later, Harris came back with news about a new program that was recently funded for the US Army Corps of Engineers (Corps)  to do wetland habitat restoration projects that were destroyed by existing projects.  This program became known as Section 1135.

Description: First, the Foundation obtained letters of support from Davis City Council, Yolo Board of Supervisors, the State Assembly and State Senate.
Description 2: Congressman Fazio then worked to get Congressional authorization and appropriation of funds for the Corps to begin the environmental documentation, state and federal permitting and engineering for the restoration of the Yolo Basin Wetlands (Section 1135 project).

Description: On 13 February 1992, Congressman Fazio, US Army Corps of Engineers and other project members held an event to celebrate the purchase of property for the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area and the initiation of the Yolo Basin Wetlands Project.
Description 2: The California Department of Fish and Wildlife signed on to be the Local Cooperating Agency. Two months later, the Army Corps released the Reconnaissance Report, Yolo Bypass, the first step for initiating a Section 1135 project.

Description: The wetland restoration design took shape over the next two years. Initial concept plans envisioned a mosaic of north-south oriented seasonal and permanent wetlands across the Cowell Ranch.
Description 2: State Fish and Wildlife Area staff including Paul Hoffman worked tirelessly with Corps staff to design the wetlands, roads, and water control structures on the recently purchased property.

Description: At the same time additional property was purchased by the Wildlife Conservation Board to provide an entrance to the new Wildlife Area and expand habitat land to the north of I-80. Thirteen acres were purchased outside the Bypass for the Wildlife Area Headquarters.
The Yolo Basin Wetlands project also included a stormwater and wastewater treatment wetland for the City of Davis. The Davis Wetlands eventually became a separate project.

For several years the Working Group met monthly to discuss many issues including the effect of creating and managing habitat in the Yolo Bypass, a key component of the Sacramento River Flood Control System.
Description 2: The effect of increased vegetation on movement of flood waters and the need to maintain a clear floodway was of paramount concern. Restoration of wetlands in a flood control area was a new concept.  Growth of emergent and riparian vegetation were seen as slowing down flood flows. There was also concern that an increased presence of endangered species, including <span class=taxon data-taxon=swahaw>Swainson hawks<span>, giant garter snakes, and winter-run salmon, would compromise the flood control agencies’ ability to maintain the floodway.

Description: Numerous other issues had to be resolved.
Description 2: Many people were concerned with the potential increase in mosquitoes near an urban area and the risk of disease. Landowners were concerned that traditional farming practices would not be tolerated near a wildlife area and their livelihood would be adversely affected.

Description: Meanwhile, Yolo Basin Foundation was busy building community support for the establishment of the new wildlife area through monthly field trips to other wetlands restoration sites and to the recently purchased property.
Description 2: The first Bucks for Ducks fundraiser was held in 1991, benefitting the wetlands project through an auction of wildlife art. Yolo Basin Foundation volunteers gave slide shows about the wildlife area concept to Yolo County business organizations and others.

Description: The first California Duck Days wetlands and wildlife festival, held February 1994, was the first of many family and educational activities centered around the Yolo Basin.

At this time, wetland restoration projects were less widespread and best practices not yet defined. Management of the future wetlands was a big issue for the Sacramento/Yolo Mosquito and Vector Control District.
Description 2: The California Department of Fish and Game and Yolo Basin Foundation worked with District leadership to design a mosquito management regime that included the use of steep slopes on ponds edges, management of vegetation and specifically timed wetland flood up and draw down. These discussions were the early development of the Mosquito Control Best Management Practices used today in managed wetlands in Northern California.

Description: In January 1994 the State Reclamation Board gave final approval of a precedent-setting Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) on Threatened and Endangered Species.
Description 2:
This agreement was facilitated and drafted by Foundation board members and finalized by State Fish and Game attorneys. It outlines a set of actions that address the concerns of state and federal flood control agencies and state and federal wildlife management agencies. The signing of this MOU represented a model of interagency cooperation that has guided other habitat restoration efforts. An agreement recognizing that flood control was the primary management goal in the Yolo Bypass was also drafted.

Representatives of The Reclamation Board, State Department of Water Resources, State Department of Fish and Game, US Fish and Wildlife Service, and the US Army Corps of Engineers signed the MOU at a special ceremony arranged by Congressman Vic Fazio in February 1994.

Description: By 1995, the designs and plans for the wetland restoration had taken shape, and construction was ready to begin! The Corps and Department of Fish and Game brought in Ducks Unlimited to manage the final design and construction of the wetlands.
Over 150 people attended the groundbreaking ceremony in front of the ready to plant riparian area adjacent to the westside levee on 17 August 1995.
Description 2: Speakers included master of ceremonies, Supervisor Betsy Marchand, Secretary of the Interior Bruce Babbitt, Congressman Vic Fazio, Brig. General Bruce Scott, USACOE, Colonel John Reese, USACOE, Michael Spear, Regional Director USFWS, Robin Kulakow, Yolo Basin Foundation, Douglas Wheeler, Secretary of California Resources Agency, Jim Sarro, Wildlife Conservation Board, and Dr. Alan Wentz, Ducks Unlimited. Yolo Basin Foundation received the Dept. of the Interior National Wetlands Conservation Award for the private sector, from Western Region, USFWS.

Description: By November 1995, after months of grading and earthwork, the first phase of construction was completed, with 800 acres of new wetland ponds.
Description 2: The next month, during the Sacramento Audubon Christmas bird count, the first flock of pintails was observed alighting over the new ponds. Construction on the remaining wetlands continued over the next two years.

Description: In summer of 1997, with the wetlands construction almost completed, Yolo Basin Foundation held the first Discover the Flyway Teachers Workshop. These workshops continue to this day. Over 1200 teachers have attended workshops prior to bringing their students to participate in a Discover the Flyway field trip.
Description 2: Education is at the heart of the Foundation’s mission, and in June 1997 the Yolo Basin Foundation signed a Memorandum of Understanding with State Fish and Game recognizing their long-term partnership to provide public outreach and educational programs.

Description: On 15 November 1997, the Wildlife Area reached the national spotlight with a dedication ceremony and opening celebration attended by President Clinton and 800 community  supporters. The ceremony marked the transfer of the Wildlife Area from the US Army Corps of Engineers, who oversaw the design and construction of the project, to the California Department of Fish and Game, who would manage it going forward.
Description 2: In addition to the President, speakers at the ceremony at Parking Lot C included Congressman Vic Fazio, John Garamendi, Assistant Deputy Director of US Dept. of the Interior, John Zhirsky, Assistant Secretary of Civil Works for US Army Corps of Engineers, Doug Wheeler, Secretary of State Resources Agency, Richard Rominger, Assistant Secretary of US Dept. of Agriculture.

Description: Yolo Basin Foundation's Robin Kulakow, Congressman Vic Fazio, Department of Interior Deputy Secretary John Garamendi and adjacent landowner and farmer Greg Schmid led President Clinton on a rainy walk along a road adjacent to the seasonal wetland ponds. Right on cue, a flock of Northern pintail flushed from the pond in a spectacular demonstration of the promise of the new wetlands.
In 1998, Yolo Basin Foundation volunteers worked with Dept. of Fish and Wildlife to construct the 3 acre Yolo  Demonstration Wetlands at the Headquarters.
Description 2: A grant from the US Fish and Wildlife Partners for Wildlife and one from the US Bureau of Reclamation Wetlands program provided funding for design, earthmoving and planting equipment. The Corps provided the riparian plants. On a very hot weekend in August 1998 a Davis Boy Scout Troop installed drip irrigation and planted 400 young trees, shrubs and grasses. The coordination of volunteers during the weekend was the culmination of an eagle scout project. Soon after the wetlands were flooded up for the first time in August 1998. The Demonstration Wetlands would soon become the core of the Foundation's educational programs.

Description: That year, the Fish and Game Operations and Maintenance Facility (Headquarters) was completed and Fish and Game staff moved in. That same year Yolo Basin Foundation opened a program office in the Headquarters alongside Dept. of Fish and Game staff.
In Spring 1998 the completion of the City of Davis Wetlands was celebrated.
Description 2: Yolo Basin Foundation volunteers lead monthly field trips in partnership with the City of Davis.

Description: Over the ensuing years, the Yolo Basin Foundation continued to grow its community footprint through the Discover the Flyway educational program, and continued to build partnerships with public agencies, land owners, and water users.

The Foundation continued to facilitate the Yolo Bypass Working Group, which it founded back in 1998 to discuss agriculture, habitat, and water management issues among the many agencies, individuals, and organizations with an interest in the Bypass. The Working Group met regularly until 2020.

The Yolo Basin Foundation has earned a reputation for collaboration with diverse public and private partners to further issues of mutual concern. Over the years it has gained the trust of the local farmers and duck club owners.

In Winter 1999, the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area was declared a Globally Important Bird Area.  The goal of the program is to identify sites in each state that are essential for sustaining naturally occurring populations of bird species and to protect or manage those sites for their long-term conservation.
Description 2: Designation of the Wildlife Area at the Global level is the highest level of recognition: “This site provides habitat for globally significant numbers of waterfowl, continentally significant numbers of Least Sandpiper and Northern Pintail and nationally significant numbers of Canvasback, Dunlin and American White Pelicans.”

Description: In the spring of 1999, the Yolo Basin Foundation moved from Robin Kulakow’s home office with the purchase of a modular office unit located at the Wildlife Area Headquarters.
Description 2: The Flyway Nights lecture series was launched that same year.

Description: Dept. of Fish and Game Manager, Dave Feliz removed the Los Rios check dam on Putah Creek on November 20, 1999, for the first time specifically for fall-run Chinook salmon migration.
Description 2: An adult salmon was spotted almost immediately starting the journey up Putah Creek to spawning gravel.

Description: In 1999, the Wildlife Area was renamed in honor of Congressman Vic Fazio Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area.
A lot was going on at the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area by Fall 1999 when Yolo Basin Foundation celebrated its 10 year anniversary with a celebration at Parking Lot B.
Description 2: By 1999, 2,000 K-12 students and their parents had visited the Wildlife Area.  Thousands of people had driven  the Auto Tour loop to view wildlife.  The hunting program was underway. Yolo Basin Foundation had a volunteer corps of over 100.

Description: In Winter 2000, the City of Davis Wetlands opened to the public. Discover the Flyway served a record 1500 students.
December 2001 saw a huge expansion of the Wildlife Area with the purchase of 12,000 additional acres of land. for the Wildlife Area.
Description 2:
The Glide Causeway Ranch, Giverson Ranch and Tule Ranch properties, along with the Los Rios Farms properties along Putah Creek, expanded the Wildlife Area to a total of 16,800 acres. This same year, the new Yolo Bypass Management Strategy was published after two years of meetings between land owners, water users, and public agencies. Work began on the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area Land Management Plan.

Dept. of Fish and Game made a commitment to maintain all existing agricultural leases on these lands until a management plan was complete and land use changes initiated. Wildlife friendly farming and ranching continued. Rice fields in the Northeast Unit were experimentally flooded in July to provide shallow water and mudflat habitat for migrating shorebirds. This experiment became the 200 acre shorebird management requirement of the rice lease on the Wildlife Area.

Description: Habitat improvements to existing seasonal  wetlands began in 2002-2003 with new water distribution systems, rebuilt  pumps and the addition of shallow benches and ridges, meandering channels, islands and scattered deep areas.
Description 2: Improvement to the water systems allows for better management to control vegetation for flood protection  and the ability to move water quickly for mosquito control.  Ducks Unlimited and California Waterfowl received grants from  North American Wetlands Conservation Act and State  Duck Stamps.

Description: Beginning in 2004, the Bat Walk and Talk program started to educate visitors about the growing colony of Mexican Free-tailed bats spending the summer roosting in the expansion joints of the Yolo Causeway.

More changes came to the Wildlife Area’s existing wetlands as additional federal funding was received in 2005-2006. The result is acres of diverse wetlands with a wide spectrum of microhabitats. These microhabitats are created by the changes in water depth as a result of swales, islands, deep areas, and low ridges created by earthmovers.
Construction of two brood ponds adjacent to I-80 began in 2007, totalling  280 acres of new brood water wetland habitat.
Description 2: Brood ponds are managed as seasonal wetlands but water is kept in the ponds through early summer for use by ducklings.

Description: Restoration completed in 2010 on a stunning 4500 acres of new wetlands on the Glide Tule Ranch, purchased by Dept. of Fish and Game in 2001.
Description 2: These include traditional managed wetlands, brood ponds, ephemeral basins, ancient slough restoration and tidal wetlands.

Description: The extension of the Auto Tour Route opened in 2011 to take visitors through active rice fields.
Description 2: If you visit in the spring you see busy farm equipment getting the soil ready for planting and flood up. In the summer you drive by lush, green rice fields. In the fall you see rice harvesters hard at work, and in the winter you see the harvested fields are flooded, attracting thousands of birds.

Description: As ecosystems change, water supply fluctuates, and new scientific knowledge develops, the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area must be actively managed to balance the parallel goals of flood protection, agriculture, wildlife conservation, recreation and education. Adapting to changing conditions requires continued partnership between agencies and land owners.
Description 2: In this section, we will learn about the mosaic of different land uses in the Wildlife Area, and the way they change seasonally throughout the year. This map outlines the fields and ponds that make up the Wildlife Area, colored by their uses. The Wildlife Area spans 16,800 acres including about 6,000 acres of wetlands.
Media Credit: Sunrise over seasonal wetlands © Skyler Lewis

Description: The Yolo Bypass provides flood protection for hundreds of thousands of people and billions of dollars of housing and infrastructure.  Flood protection comes first.  Habitat restoration projects must all be flood neutral, meaning vegetation must not slow down flood waters, roads and internal levees must by under 3 feet.  All improvements require approval of the Flood Protection Board.
Description 2: In spring 2011, when this aerial photo was taken, inundation of the Yolo Bypass began in March.  Flood waters of 100,000 cubic feet per second moved through the Bypass.
Map Credit: Aerial photo mosaic from the March-April 2011 flood event, showing visible sediment plumes corresponding to flows from the four major tributaries of the Yolo Bypass. Source: USGS High Resolution Orthoimagery (201104_sacramento_ca_0x3000m_utm_clr)

Description: Semi-permanent ponds, 4 to 5 feet deep, are filled with water year-round except when drained for vegetation removal or infrastructure improvements.
Description 2:
These ponds provide year-round habitat for the area's resident waterfowl, including those that nest in the Wildlife Area during the spring and summer: including American Coots, Mallards, Gadwall, Cinnamon Teal, and Ruddy Ducks.

Green's Lake in the northeast is a remnant oxbow lake that dates back to the pre-development Sacramento River Valley.

Description: Seasonal wetlands are shallower, 6-18 inches deep. These ponds, planted with tule and cattail, are flooded beginning in October. They begin to dry out between February and April.
Description 2: Wetlands are flooded in September/October to provide wintering habitat for large numbers of migratory waterfowl and shorebirds.
Media Credit: Seasonal wetlands along the auto loop © Skyler Lewis

Description: Seasonal wetlands are drained between February and April before invasive weeds can establish. They are mowed and disced on a 3 to 5 year rotation. If water is available, the seasonal wetlands can be irrigated once to encourage growth of beneficial wetland plants. Some wetlands are first partially drained to provide shallow spring shorebird habitat.
Wetland-associated grasslands provide cover for ground nesting birds. Limited riparian habitat lines some of the ditches.
Media Credit: Upland habitat from the Tule Trail © Skyler Lewis

Description: Putah Creek flows into the Wildlife Area from the west, carrying water from Lake Berryessa and downstream tributaries.
Description 2: The Creek eventually flows into the toe drain that runs alongside the levee of the Sacramento Deep Water Ship Canal, and out to the Delta.

Description: Stretches of riparian woodland and scrub line water bodies including Putah Creek and Green's Lake.
Description 2: Trees such as cottonwood, willow, oregon ash, box elder, and blue elderberry support land mammals and nesting birds of prey.
Media Credit: Tree line from the road to Lot C © Skyler Lewis

Description: Alongside dedicated wetlands, the Wildlife Area also supports 2,400 acres of rice cultivation.
Description 2: Rice is planted in May-June and harvested in September. This collaboration between local rice growers and the state helps with land management costs and creates bird friendly habitat.

Description: After the harvest, starting in November, the rice fields are flooded to provide additional expanses of wetland habitat for migratory waterfowl and shorebirds.
Description 2: Fields are eventually drained the next March as migratory waterfowl and shorebirds begin to head north, to prepare for the next season's harvest.

Description: Rice farmers are required to set aside two parcels of land for summertime shorebird habitat.
Description 2: These areas (which change year to year) are flooded in succession in July and August to provide the shallow water foraging habitat preferred by migrating shorebirds returning to the wildlife area in late summer..

Description: About 5,000 acres of irrigated and dryland pasture provide upland habitat alongside grazing range.
Description 2: The Wildlife Area used to be farmed in row crops including tomatoes; the Department of Fish and Wildlife sometimes plants safflower, corn and milo as a food crop for pheasants.
Media Credit: Snow geese with cows in the Causeway Ranch unit

Description: The grasslands of the Tule Ranch section of the Wildlife Area include rare vernal pool and playa pool formations—ephemeral wetlands formed in shallow depressions that fill throughout the rainy season.
Description 2: As they dry in the spring, characteristic rings of wildflowers form along the receding shoreline in response to changing soil moisture. Flowers include goldfields, miniature lupine, butter-and-eggs, dowingia, monkey flower, and tidy tips. These pools contain a high diversity of plant species including some that are endangered. Several species of fairy shrimp live in the pools including the endangered Conservancy and Tadpole Fairy Shrimp.
Media Credit: Vernal pools and the umbrella barn at Glide Tule Ranch © Skyler Lewis

Description: The Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area is located off Interstate 80 between Davis and Sacramento.
Description 2: Take exit 78 from I-80 to visit the wildlife area (just east of the exit) and the headquarters (2 miles west on Chiles Rd).
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: Take advantage of the popular auto tour loop for year-round wildlife viewing that passes through permanent ponds, seasonal wetlands, and rice fields.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: Several hiking trails are accessible year round.
Description 2: Get out of the car at Parking Lot C and take the loop along the Tule Trail to see seasonal wetlands to the west and permanent ponds to the east.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: In the late fall and winter, the Wildlife Area is a hunting destination.
Description 2: Duck hunting season begins in October and extends through January, while pheasant season begins mid-November. The hunting area begins at a check-point and is separate from the year-round public wildlife viewing zone.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: Outside of hunting season, expanded public access begins in February. Catch the tail end of the migratory waterfowl season, and the bountiful shorebird display in the spring.
Description 2: These trails are open until hunting begins again in October.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: The demonstration wetlands at the headquarters are as start of field trips to the wildlife area and other local destinations like grasslands.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: The Yolo Basin Foundation's outdoor ecucation program, Discover the Flyway, hosted 60,000 students in its first decade (1997-2017).
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: In a series of tours each fall, YBF naturalists take visitors to see the largest urban colony of Mexican free-tailed bats in California.
Description 2: The migratory bats roost under the Yolo Causeway, and at sunset fly out in a spectacular cloud to feed.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: And in the spring, YBF leads guided wildflower tours of the vernal pools at Glide Tule Ranch and Grasslands Regional Park.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: The Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area hosts a diverse range of bird species that vary from season to season: ducks and geese that migrate long distances to the bypass in the winter, spring shorebirds foraging in shallow wetlands, summer nesting waterfowl and year-round residents, blackbirds flocking among tule reeds, and birds of prey hunting overhead.
Description 2: This section describes some of the common birds seen at the Wildlife Area. For a full list, take a look at the bird observations on eBird.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: Spectacular numbers of wintering waterfowl come to the Wildlife Area starting in October.
Description 2: The most common duck visitors are the northern pintail and the northern shoveler, but also look for the American widgeon, green-winged teal, canvasback, common goldeneye, and bufflehead. Pintails arrive as early as august, but most birds start arriving in October, peaking in December. They head north again come March and April.
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: Wintering geese and swans tend to arrive in November, with over 10,000 snow geese and greater white-fronted geese visiting each season.
Description 2: Ross's geese, and tundra swans also visit. Geese arrive from as far north as Banks Island in the Arctic Archipelago and Wrangel Island off the north coast of Russia.
Media Credit: Flooded rice fields serve as important winter habitat for Pacific Flyway migratory birds such as Snow Geese. Aerial footage filmed and edited by Eric Holmes of the UC Davis Center for Watershed Sciences.
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: Other waterfowl stay closer to home.
Description 2: Birds like the coot, mallard, gadwall, and cinnamon teal—along with some shovelers— nest at the Wildlife Area during the summer. Look for broods of ducklings on the permanent ponds in May through July.
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: Great blue herons, great egrets, snowy egrets, American bitterns and white pelicans, can also be found in the Wildlife Area year-round.
Waders like the white-faced ibis nest in the tule marsh over the summer and forage in the rice fields in the fall.
Many shorebirds (including avocets, black-necked stilts, killdeer, and coots) nest in the wildlife area in April, with chicks appearing in May.
Other shorebirds (including black-bellied plovers, greater yellowlegs, and long-billed dowitchers) head north in April to nest, returning to the wildlife area mid-summer.

Still others (phalaropes, willets, godwits, and some sandpipers) use the Wildlife Area as a stop on their migration to their northern summer breeding grounds, visiting in both the spring and late fall.
Look among the tangle of tule and cattails for red-winged blackbird, marsh wren, and rails like the Virginia rail and sora.
The grassland ecosystems host western meadowlark, yellow-billed magpie, and tree swallows.
Birds of prey include the red-tailed hawk, swainson's hawk, and northern harrier.
Description 2: Swainson's hawks arrive from the South in April to nest, staying through September, while other raptors can be spotted year-round.

Description: ...and check the trees for great horned owls!
The Yolo Bypass is a landscape in flux.
Description 2: The Yolo Basin Foundation and its partners continue to work together to keep improving ecological function and meeting the needs of the Bypass's array of users and inhabitants.
Map Credit: 2018 NAIP (National Agricultural Imagery Program) aerial orthophotos taken 14-15 July 2018. Source: USGS

Description: Careful management is required to balance the hydrologic benefits of the Los Rios Check Dam with the migratory needs of salmonid fish.
Description 2: Along with the Lisbon Weir and Road 106A crossing, the Los Rios Check Dam is a partial barrier to salmonid migration between Lake Solano on Putah Creek and the Bay-Delta estuary. The Yolo Basin Foundation and its partners coordinate the seasonal removal of wooden flashboards to facilitate the fall passage of Chinook salmon, and future fish ladder improvements are in the works.

Description: Future restoration projects in the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area will work to restore riparian, floodplain, and tidal marsh habitats.
Description 2: The Lower Putah Creek Restoration Project is currently under development and funded by an Ecosystem Restoration Program grant. A new naturalized channel for Lower Putah Creek, surrounded by seasonally inundated floodplain wetlands and riparian forest, would connect to the Toe Drain through a 90-acre restored freshwater tidal marsh. The proposed route bypasses the Los Rios Check Dam and Lisbon Weir for more direct fish passage from the Bay-Delta estuary to their upstream spawning habitat at Lake Solano.

Description: An array of restoration projects are already underway throughout the greater Yolo Bypass, promising expanded floodplain habitat for salmonid fish.
Description 2: The Yolo Bypass Salmonid Habitat Restoration and Fish Passage Project, including a "big notch" constructed upstream in the Fremont Weir, will increase water flows into the Bypass.  Juvenile steelhead and Chinook salmon will benefit from a larger and longer-lived food-rich floodplain rearing habitat, and adults will face fewer delays when returning to their upstream spawning grounds.

Description: Ongoing partnerships between the Yolo Basin Foundation, county and state agencies work to mitigate adverse flooding impacts caused by increased flows.
Description 2: The Yolo Bypass Drainage and Water Infrastructure Improvement Study outlines drainage network improvements in and around the Wildlife Area, including new control structures, higher-capacity canals, and new bridge crossings.
